Would you like some surpries with that order?

I don't have any other guesses about the Keen enemy in the The Surprimpsons (The Simprises?) episode, since I don't have the means to watch the series, and random guesses don't really do a whole lot.

By the way, if I'm talking about the "The Simpsons" series, should I use the word "the" twice?
I say I do, because leaving out one means either I'm not using the correct title, or I'm breaking a proper sentence.
However, most other people claim it's simply wrong to write "the the", with no explanation.
I guess those are the people that write a sentence between brackets, end with a smiley [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] and leave out the closing bracket because the smiley already has one.
Maybe it's because of my familiarity with programming languages that this seems very wrong to me, but it just doesn't make sense to me to leave stuff out like that.
I tried to look this up, but couldn't find any conclusive evidence.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: gah
content:
By default, HTML doesn't allow for two spaces after a period, either. In fact, even if you manually press the space bar twice, the HTML will format it out, unless you use the &space charcter, whatever it is. The internet is changing the way we communicate. Cel phones, too, for that matter.

Plz get eggs bred n butr @ stor. luv u c u 2nite.

Hooray for language evolving!

title: Re: re
content:
Ah, but if you only have a parser that recognises brackets, then ending with a smiley keeps the bracket count consistent, otherwise you'll have one too many closing brackets. On the other hand, if your parser is smiley-aware, it will treat the smiley as a separate token and it won't count in the overall bracket count (in which case you would need two closing brackets [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img] )

I'm still to decide which way is better, although now smileys are more common I'm leaning towards the double-bracket style.

As to The Simpsons, I think the best way is to borrow part of the title and use it in the sentence, e.g. "I'm talking about The Simpsons series" or better yet, just reword it to avoid the issue - "I'm talking about the series 'The Simpsons'"

Either way too many 'the's only confuses people who aren't used to a computer's level of logic [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: re
content:
Well, html has some annoying problems involving space characters, but it's okay in total.

Yes, since you are referring to 'The SImpsons' you should include to 'the's but the second should be captialized, older etiquitte says the title should be italicized as well.

While cellphones are making us more social, they are unlikely to change the structure of the english language as a whole, though it has created its own jargon. Txt as a written language works, never as a spoken one and the two are likely to remain seperate. English as a language is indeed evolving, and has done so to the point that there are dialects that are incomprehensible to others, notable cockney english.

Goodlanguage and writing skills are vital in order to compete in the cut-throat world of business and the global ecconomy; the standards of some people's writing never ceases to appal me.

Billy Blaze got a perfect A+ on his english tests; an example for all of us.

title: Re: gah
content:
HTML doesn't really remove extra spaces, luckily, but every browser (that's compliant with the HTML specs) will ignore the excess ones for the page render.
This is useful when aligning the source, not wanting to influence the render.
I understand Americans prefer to use two spaces between sentences, after the period, but even if they do, it doesn't carry over in the render, unless they use " ".

That means "non-breaking space" because if I link (use not limited to just links though) "this sentence here" and "this" is the last word to fit on the line, "sentence here" drops down a line, and moves to the left (or right, depending on the language setting), which usually looks bad, and can be avoided.

I recently discovered the zero-width space, "​" (no human-friendly variant for this one), which I consider to do the "opposite".
Supercalifragilistic​expialidocious breaks up the word around the middle when it doesn't fit on the line.
This also gives you more control on how your page renders on different resolutions, browser window sizes, etc..

As for the "The" issue, I usually try to avoid it, but sometimes it makes for really artificial-looking/-sounding sentences, like the ones you sometimes get when trying to not end with a preposition.

I didn't know about the italics... well, I didn't know anything of the rules like I said, so thanks for the information people! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: gah
content: Actually I thought it was proper British English that said you needed two spaces after a full stop - at any rate like you say, the beauty of HTML is that you can type in the source however you see fit and then your browser should render it correctly.  So in other words, if you're only seeing one space after a full stop, you should be blaming your browser for not rendering the source in accordance with your language rules.

title: Re: gah
content: you can always use the <pre> </pre> tags to make the text appear exactly as you type it.[img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] - .... . / ..-  -. .. ...- . .-. ... . / .. ... / - --- .- ... - / .-.

title: Re: gah
content: Except then it doesn't word wrap, so you have to know how wide a user's screen is and wrap it by hand, which is next to impossible.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Hehehe, I won't point out the misspelling of "economy" then, but I'm having a hard time ignoring "two" misspelled as "to" (you should include *two* "the"s)[hr][/quote]

Forgive me; I left out the 'w' and didn't notice. This is because I look at the keyboard when I type and not the screen. Other words I dislike are any that are American spelled with 'o' instead of 'ou' and things with single 'b's that sound like doubles, such as probability.

Also, you used '"' instead of ''' when quoting your words, that is technically incorrect and should only be used for direct quotations. Consider this a correction correction correction.
